 PAKISTAN PUNJAB PRIVATE SECTOR GROUNDWATER DEVELOPMENT PROJECT 1. SECTORAL BACKGROUND A. Introduction I . I The groundwater use has been a major factor in the growth of agricultural production in Pakistan over the past two decades. Groundwater tubewells not only supply additional water but have provided flexibility to match canal water supplies with crop water requirements. Before 1960s the development of the groundwater tubewells was limited to open dug wells operated by animal power mostly outside the canal command areas. Large scale development of groundwater resources was first attempted by the Government under Salinity Control and Reclamation Projects (SCARPs program) for controlling waterlogging and salinity. Under the SCARP projects, about 13,500 publically owned and operated tubewells were installed. In areas underlain by fresh groundwater (FGW), water from SCARP tubewells (STWs) was used to supplement canal supplies. SCARP tubewells had a significant demonstrative effect in starting private tubewell development in fresh groundwater areas. As a result, private tubewells (PTWs) grew rapidly and there are now more than 300,000 private tubewells in the country. With rapidly growing private sector and declining performance of SCARP tubewells, there is need for redefining the role of the Government in the groundwater development. Hence, redefinition of this role in Punjab's groundwater development sector is the main objective of this project. 1.2 The project builds on the experiences of SCARP Transition, Irrigation Systems Rehabilitation. On-Farm Water Management programs and Private Tubewell Development Projects. This staff appraisal report is based on the preparation report' by the Government with assistance of UNDP2 and the findiiigs of Pre-Appraisal and Appraisal missions which visited Punjab during July, 1994 and June, 1995. respectively. B. Agricultural Sector 1.3 Although the share of agriculture in the economy has been slowly decreasing, it is still the backbone of the economy, employing more than 50 percent of the labor force and earning (directly or indirectly) 70 percent of export revenues3. Total cultivated area is 21 million hectares (ha), with overall cropping intensity of 101 percent. About 55 percent of the cropped area is under food-grains, the most important of which are wheat and rice. The main cash crops are cotton and sugarcane, grown on 12.4 and 4 percent of land, respectively. Cotton and high quality rice (Basmati) are important export crops, and Pakistan is one of the leading cotton exporters in the world. Other major crops include fodder, fruit and vegetables.  1.4 Most of the poor live in rural areas. Agriculture has particularly strong interaction with rural poverty. Flight from rural areas is a contributing factor to urban poverty. Although absolute poverty in Pakistan declined from 40 percent of rural population in the early-1960s to 25 percent by the mid 1980s, this reduction is much less than East Asian countries with similar agricultural growth rates. Agriculture is the primary user of natural resources --land and water resources. The development in the sector has a direct impact on the incidence and pattern of poverty, natural resource management and environmental protection, andi therefore, on sustainable development. 1.5 The sector has generally performed well, growing by more than three percent per annum over the last three decades. The sources of growth have changed over the years: during the 1960s, growth was mostly the result of the rapid uptake of the improved seed, fertilizer and irrigation packages; during the 1970s it was the intensification of water and fertilizer use; and in the 1980s it was improvement in crop management and incentives. The Government of Pakistan (GOP) has recently launched a major economic reform progranm with the objectives of adjustment and growth. Agriculture would have to play an important role in this process. However. there is limited scope for expanding cultivable land or irrigation supplies and future growth has to rely on more efficient use of limited resources. There is a particular need to ensure efficiency and sustainability in the management of land and water, which are the two most important natural resources. Irrigation Sector 1.6 Pakistan's agriculture is almost wholly dependent on irrigation --irrigated land supplies more than 90 percent of agricultural production. Agriculture in most areas is not possible without irrigation because the climate in Pakistan is arid to semi-arid witlh low and variable rainfall. Annual rainfall over much of area is not more than 150 mm per annum, and evaporation is very high, ranging from 1,250 mm to 2,800 mm per annum. However, there are abundant surface water resources in the Indus Basin, which covering 566,000 km2 (70 percent of the country), is the major source of Pakistan's water. The Indus Basin Irrigation System commands about 14 million ha which accounts for the bulk of the agriculturally productive land. Annual river inflows average about 180 billion m3 of which about 130 billion m3 are diverted to canals. The Indus Basin Irrigation System is composed of three major reservoirs (Chasma, Mangla and Tarbela)4, 19 barrages, 12 link canals, 43 canal conmnands and over 107,000 watercourses. The length of the canals is about 58,000 km, with communal watercourses (W/C), farm channels and field ditches running another 1.6 million km. 1.7 In the Indus systein, river water is diverted by barrages and weirs into main canals and subsequently into branch canal, distributaries and minors. Open, free-flowing outlets (moghas) regulate water flow from distributaries and minors to W/Cs. Watercourse command area (chak) is a complex miniature irrigation system with an average length of channels of 16 km. Water distribution to the field is governed by a weekly time rotation (warabandi) based on the size of the land holding. 1.8 The canal system is also a major source of recharge for the groundwater. In fresh areas, groundwater is pumped by public and private tubewells to supplement canal supplies. About 11,000 publically owned and operated STWs currently pump approximately 9 billion m3 annually. Pumpage from STWs, however, is declining. On the other hand, with rapidly growing number of private tubewells (PTWs) pumpage from groundwater is over 60 billion mi. STWs pump water in the communal watercourses and it is distributed through the warabandi system. PTWs are mostly located on the farms and farmers have more flexibility in their operation. Water supply from public tubewells is relatively less significant --less than 15 percent of total groundwater pumpage or equivalent of less than 7 percent Total live storage capacity of three reservoirs is about 18 billion m'.
 of canal water diversions. However, public tubewells require about half of Government's irrigation operation and maintenance (O&M) expenditures. 1.9 Flat topography and lack of well-defined natural drainage in the Indus Plain create a surface drainage problem. The problem has been compounded by the construction of roads, railways, flood embankments and irrigation systems that obstruct natural flows. The irrigation systems were developed without provision of drainage. Over the years, about 14,000 km of surface drains have been constructed in Punjab and more recently in the tail reaches of Rohri and Nara canal commands in Sindh. The surface and subsurface drainage systems are inadequate. Under SCARPs, attempts were made to meet the subsurface drainage iieeds through deep tubewells. A limited area is provided with tile drainage. 1. 10 About 2.2 million ha of irrigated land is outside Indus canal commanded area (cca), scattered in relatively small parcels with water coming from open wells, tubewells, lift pumps, karezes, springs, and small diversions. Generally, water supply in these system is uncertain and varies with season and location. Farmers have a major role in the management of these systems and some of these were developed by communities themselves. Normally, these system do not suffer from waterlogging and salinity problems. 1.11 While the irrigation and drainage systems are central to Pakistan's economy, they are facing severe problems. Despite Government's substantial budgetary input, the system is facing a shortage of resources and suffering from severe and worsening operational problems. In addition to water scarcity, major problems facing the sector are: inefficient management of water systems (that is low delivery efficiency, and inequitable distribution); waterlogging and salinity; over exploitation of groundwater in fresh groundwater areas: inadequate O&M; and insufficient cost recovery. The average delivery efficiency is reported to be about 35 to 40 percent from the canal head to the root zone, but actual is even worse. Most of the losses are in the watercourses. The loss of such a major part of surface water not only reduces available water for crops but it also contributes to waterlogging and salinity. Another serious problem is inequitable distribution. Excessive losses compared with the original desigin also meanis that water does not reach the tail end of the system. Moreover, illegal pumping from canals adds to the inequity of distribution. Poorly maintained watercourses have the highest incidence of illegal diversions. Many of the above problems are worsened by an excessive Government role with inadequate participation of the beneficiaries in the system management. C. Groundwater Potential and Development . 12 Most of the Indus Basin has been formed as a result of alluvium deposits derived by rivers from the miountaini ranges in the north. These alluvial deposits consist principally of fine and medium- grained sands and silts. although there are discontinuous lenses of silt and clay. Their depth ranges from 450( m in upper Punjab to about 60 m in lower Sindh, where it is layered with silty and heavy deltaic sediment. There is a vast unconfined aquifer of around 6 million ha covering most of this area. The water table is mostly high and has been rising due to lack of drainage. The hydrogeological conditions are mostly favorable for pumping by tubewells. Groundwater quality is variable, ranging from fresh near the major rivers to highly saline further away. In some areas, groundwater is saline even near the rivers due to local salt deposits. In total, about 79 percent of the area in Punjab and 28 percent of the area in Sindh has fresh groundwater5 which is suitable for irrigation. However, the residual sodium carbonate (RSC) which results from use of groundwater is often high. Exclusive reliance on groundwater can lead to a build-up of salts. resulting in binding of the soil structure, reduced water infiltration into the root zone and falling yields. Ideally, groundwater should be mixed with canal water for irrigation use. Total dissol ed salt less than 1 .200 ppm and electrical conductivity less than 2 mmhos.
 -4- Public Tubewell Development 1.13 By the 1950s, large areas in the Indus basin became waterlogged and soil salinity increased, adversely affecting the agricultural productivity. Government involvement in the groundwater development began with efforts to control the "twin menaces" of waterlogging and salinity by providing drainage. The Government embarked on a series of SCARPs in the late-1950s aimed at lowering the groundwater table by providing "vertical drainage" through large capacity. deep tubewells (60-140 liters per second capacities and depth of 40-120 meters). Because of better economic returns, priority was given to locating SCARPs in the areas where groundwater quality was suitable for supplemental irrigationi, making the drainage a by-product in effect. Over the last three decades about 13,500 STWs have been installed by the Government in 36 projects covering a gross area of about 3.7 million ha. Most of the STWs were equipped with electrically powered motors and deep turbine pumps with a relatively large capacity of about 3 cusecs (.085 cubic meters/second). Almost 75 percent of all STWs were installed in the Punjab --8,000 in fresh groundwater areas and 1.800 in saline groundwater areas. In saline grounidwater areas the STWs pumped water into drains or, when this was not possible, into the larger canals. In FGW areas, water from STWs was normally pumped into watercourses and used for irrigation along with surface water sL, plies. Bank involvement in public tubewell development was limitetd to ilstallation of STWs in saline areas of Punjab under SCARP VI project (Cr. 0754-PAK). 1.14 Performance and Sustainability of SCARP Tubewells. STWs were generally successful in meeting their objective of maintaining the groundwater tables at desirable levels and providing a supplemilentary source of irrigation. Their performance, however, declined over time due to poor management and inadequate availability of funds for O&M. Presently, most of the STWs are very old, equipment has worn out resulting in frequent breakdowns, and well capacities' are significantly below their original designs. In Punjab, about half of STWs are below 50 percent of original capacity and only 15 percent have more than 80 percent. The utilization of STWs at present is considerably lower than it was originally and water supplies have become unreliable due to the factors mentioned above and prolonged blackouts due to power shortage and an unreliable public grid. 1.15 The O&M costs of STWs have increased mlainyfold due to rapidly increasing power tariffs, wages and mainitenance and replacement requirements. Presently, the Punjab Irrigation Departmenit (PID) is responsible for all O&M costs of STWs. These cost include electricity charges, repair and mainteniance, operation of special workshops for repairs, salary of a full-time operator and higher managemiient, and other establishment costs. Funding for O&M of these tubewells is provided to PID by the Government of Punjab (GOPunjab) through non-development budgetary allocations. Expenditures for O&M of STWs in FGW areas of Punjab during fiscal year 1994-95 were almost equal to O&M expenditures on canals while actual requirement were even more. Budget allocations for O&M of STWs in 1995-96 exceed the allocations for canals. Annually they are more than Rs. 150,000/STW. 1.16 Water charges (abiania) are based on crop acreage and type of crop. In Punjab, farmers receiving water from canals as well as from STWs are liable for paying double water charge (double abianaia). (twice the amount of farmers receiving water from canals only). However, present water charges only recover about 35 percent of provincial O&M costs on the irrigation and drainage systems. Since O&M cost of STWs, per unit of water supplied, is much higher than canals, the provincial subsidy for the O&M of STWs is many times more than for canals. Despite these expenditures water delivery service from STWs has deteriorated due to institutional deficiencies. These include lack of motivation and accountability of agency staff, high levels of political interference and rent seeking, as well as inadequate conicerin for the needs of users.  1.17 The void created due to institutional weaknesses is filled to some extent by informal farmers' groups which have sprung up in STW areas. These groups look after daily operations, such as switching on the pumps' and regular maintenance. They also carry out repairs using local mechanics, electricians and other services from the local markets. Funds for these repairs are usually collected on an ad hoc basis from the benefiting farmers. However, farmers find it difficult to carry out repairs involving the main shaft of turbine pumps as it requires specialized equipment available from PID workshops. Nevertheless, they do follow up and assist PID in expediting such repairs. 1.18 The operation of STWs in the public sector is unsustainable due to institutional weaknesses as well as financial and economic reasons. The institutional weakness essentially arise from centralized management and lack of transparency without any formal participation of beneficiaries. Due to the overall resource scarcity Pakistan is facing presently, it is becoming increasingly difficult to allocate adequate funds for operation of STWs, and replacement of old ones. The economic cost of pumping water by elect:iuity operated STW is much higher (Rs. 0.20 per cubic meter) than diesel operated shallow tubewells (Rs. 0. 10 per cubic meter). Private Tubewell Development 1.19 A virtuil explosion in the private tubewells development followed the introduction of tubewell technology by the public sector. Currently there are over 300,000 PTWs installed for irrigation purposes, of which 80 percent are in the Punjab supplying 40 percent of all irrigation water. PTWs are predominantly small shallow wells which use locally manufactured engines and centrifugal pumps. Their average capacity is one cusec (0.028 ml per second) with maximum size of two cusecs. More importantly, as yields and input levels rose, so did the importance of timely and adequate water supplies. By installing PTWs, farmers reduce their risks of crop failure and improve yields by smoothing out natural and operational fluctuations ;n water supplies from the canal system. Even in the STWs areas of Punjab there are more than 50,000 PTWs. While returns to tubewells are high, the utilization rates are very low. PTWs are used by both headenders and tailenders, although the tailenders rely more on groundwater. Most PTWs are owned by medium to large farmers with holdings of five hectares or more. Presently, there is neither any mechanism for allocating groundwater rights nor for regulating its use. Any land owner can install a tubewell and begin pumping groundwater and in some areas there has been over-exploitation due to anarchic private tubewell development. Community Tubewell Development 1.20 There are a very limited number of community tubewells (CTWs) in operation, many of which date back to the early 1960s with roots in the cooperative movement. The CTWs are set up and operated by informal farmers' organizations with day to day management entrusted to one person who is paid an honorarium. Like STWs, CTWs pump water into watercourses and this is shared either on the basis of fixed turns (varabandi), on demand, or a mixture of both. The basis for levying charges also varies. Charges are levied either on the basis of irrigated land, hours supplied, or both.8 Within the CTW command, farmers also supplement supplies through PTWs. Recently, about 550 CTWs in Punjab and 150 CTWs in Sindh have been installed under Second SCARP Transition Project (Cr. 2257- PAK). Behavior of Groundwater Aquifers 1.21 In the Indus Basin as a whole, recharge to the groundwater aquifers and extractions' are in balance." However, in the fresh groundwater areas of Punjab pumpage exceeds recharge and as a result the water table is falling. In contrast, in the saline areas the water table is rising. The same holds true in SCARP areas. In all FGW SCARP water tables are falling." This situation has reduced the need for drainage to lower groundwater table, and unlike the original objectives of providing drainage - -a public good, the STWs are merely supplying irrigation water which is a private good. Therefore, government involvement in the operation of STWs is no longer justifiable. 1.22 Regulation of Groundwater Use. In the past rising and not falling groundwater tables were the major problem. Therefore, government encouraged the installation of tubewells through tax incentives and subsidies. The situation now is reversing in most of FGW areas, therefore, for sustainable use of groundwater resources the need for enforcement of suitable regulations is more pressing now. Existing legislation'2 include provisions for the control over groundwater aquifers, however, these were never implemented, mainly because regulation was seen unnecessary. The monitoring, and regulation of groundwater exploitation is a government function. However, to enable government to regulate groundwater use successfully, its institutional capacity has to be enhanced in groundwater monitoring, refining regulation requirements, assessments of safe cxploitation levels and allocation of rights, staffing, technical competence, and organizational arrangements for implementation of regulatory functions. While the proposed National Drainage Program would strengthen national capacity for groundwater monitoring, the project would address local monitoring for the implementation of regulations, assessment of sustainable yields from aquifers as well as capacity for implementing regulations. D. Bank Group Assistance Strategy 1.23 The overall objective of the Bank's assistance strategy in Pakistan is to help reduce poverty. To address this objective, the Bank's approach highlights two closely linked challenges: improving the inadequate basic social services and reducing constraints to sustained growth. Expanding access to and improving the quality of basic social services are essential to improve living standards in Pakistan, which now has dismal social indicators. In addition to assisting the completion of fiscal adjustment, the Bank's strategy is to support the growth objectives by focusing on structural reforms, improving the enabling environment for the private sector, strengthening inadequate basic infrastructure, Groundwater aquifers are recharged by rain, rivers, seepage from canals. watercourses and fields.  reducing constraints on agriculture productivity, and protecting Pakistan's natural resource base. In focussing assistance on public policy, institutional development, critical public investments for private sector led growth, and strengthening the basis for private investments, the Bank is assisting the redefinition of the public and private sectors in Pakistan. 1.24 In agriculture, the focus of our policy dialogue is on reshaping the public and private sector roles. The Bank supports maintaining a high rate of agricultural growth, with emphasis on further improving the link between agricultural growth and poverty alleviation, and ensuring environmentally sustainable agricultural development. The Bank's short- and medium-term assistance will focus on: (a) redefining the roles of the public and private sectors in all aspects of agriculture with fundamental shifts in the irrigation and drainage subsector towards more decentralized and participatory management systems; (b) reducing distortions in input and output prices and trade regimes; (c) improving efficiency of agricultural public expenditures; (d) strengthening natural resource management by emphasizing local institutions: and (e) strengthening support services to increase productivity and diversify agriculture. 1.25 In irrigation and drainage, Bank is encouraging the Government to adopt a completely new approach.'3 Consistent with the country assistance strategy, the goals of establishing an efficient, self-sustaining irrigation and drainage system are to be achieved by promoting the use of market- determined incentives for improving the supply and management of irrigation and drainage services, and by giving the private sector a greater stake in the system. The irrigation service would be decentralized and privatized by developing commercially oriented public utilities (PUs) on a canal command basis, and suitable FOs. and by formalizing water rights and water markets. Autonomous provincial authorities would be developed for water delivery to PUs and handling off-farm drainage and regulatory bodies for regulating the PUs and groundwater resources. 1.26 The restructuring of irrigation services cannot be achieved immediately, and must be done in steps for successful implementation. The transformation of surface systems would be implemented through a series of canal command level pilot projects in which PUs and FOs will be formed. The total transition may take from 15 to 20 years. These pilots are under preparation in all provinces and would be supported through other projects or sector loans such as National Drainage and Irrigation Programs. While implementation of the strategy in the surface systems is still evolving, considerable experience already exists in the country in private tubewell development and divestment of public tubewells. Building upon this experience, the proposed project would be a major step towards implementing the irrigation and drainage strategy in groundwater sector while leading the way for reforms in the management of the surface systems. It fits into the Bank Group's country assistance strategy as it would provide assistance in: (a) redefining the role of government in the groundwater development; (b) assigning groundwater rights and developing regulatory framework for ensuring sustainable use of groundwater resources; (c) improving water use efficiency; (d) rationalizing public expenditures for O&M of the irrigation and drainage systems, and strengthening the principles of capital cost recovery in the sector; (e) enhancing community participation, thereby, building a solid base for ultimately transferring all irrigation systems to the beneficiaries; and (f) protecting the environment by controlling saline water intrusion into fresh aquifers. Lessons Learned 1.30 There can be no doubt that the provision of irrigation and drainage facilities have had a major positive impact on agricultural production in Pakistan. It is also evident that farmers generally respond well when provided with reliable and timely irrigation service. Nevertheless, there is room for considerable improvement in all aspects of planning, design, implementation and O&M of irrigation systems. The Bank-supported projects have suffered implementation delays due to slow GOP approval process, delays in recruitment of consultants, inadequate procurement procedures and inadequately capitalized contractors, unresponsive managemuent, and problems in inter-agency coordination. In order to avoid delays due to GOP approvals, the preparation of PC-I`9 was started immediately following the project appraisal and it has been approved by the Provincial Development Working Party (PDWP). Similarly, recruitment of project implementation consultants has been completed before Board presentation. Bank's Standard Bidding Documents (BSBDs) would be used to reduce delays due to procurement procedures, improve transparency and attract well-capitalized reputable contractors. For smooth implementation as well as to allow flexibility, the project would be implemented through a separate Project Management Unit (PMU), with a minimal staff but supported by management and social consultants. 1.31 Beneficiary Participation. In the past, government planned, implemented and operated the irrigation and drainage system without much consultation with the beneficiaries. Farmers started to play a significant role under IDA assisted On-Farm Water Management Prograrn (OFWM). Under OFWM, formal Water Users' Associations were formed and registered to contribute to the lining of watercourses. In Punjab, WUAs' provide skilled (masons) and urskilled labor, 30 percent of the material cost in six installments over three years, and provide assistance in supervising the implementation. The WUAs play a critical role in improving watercourses. However, many become inactive after completion of civil works. The main reason for their inactivity is that Government keeps control of irrigation water as well as revenue collection, water supply increases slightly while O&M requirements reduce. As a result, WUAs do not have any function essential for operation of irrigation systems. Several measures are taken in the proposed project towards developing sustainable FOs. FOs will be involved in planning, implementation and O&M of irrigation facilities, especially the CTWs. FOs will control water supply from the tubewells and have a continuous function --supplying water to its members, collecting revenue and carrying out O&M without interference from any Government agency. They will remain active in such an environment. The FOs would decide about the tubewell type (taking over STWs as such, with modification or installing new ones, electric or diesel), machinery, size, and location of the CTWs. Other civil works will be constructed after the successful functioning of FOs for at least one year. FOs will collect funds, operate bank accounts, and plan and participate in the construction and improvement of surface systems. Encouraging PTWs to replace STWs results in anarchy, building excessive capacity leading to over-capitalization and excessive O&M costs; danger of over-exploitation of groundwater, inequity in water supply, as well as improper conjunctive use of canal and groundwater. Physical Features Location 2.1 The project area lies in the central and southern parts of Punjab Province and falls within Gujranwala, Sargodha, Faisalabad, Multan and Lahore administrative Divisions (see Maps IBRD 27738 and 27739).23 It consists of fresh groundwater areas of SCARP II (including Shahpur), SCARP III (Rangpur Unit), SCARP IV and SCARP V (Shorkot Kamalia). Climate and Soils 2.2 The Punjab (and the project areas) have a continental sub-tropical climate, ranging from sub-humid in the north-east to arid in the south-west, with hot summers and mild winters. The average monthly maximum temperatures range from 20C in the winter to over 420C in the summer, with May and June being the hottest months prior to monsoon rains. The minimum temperatures fall below 5C in the winter, with December and January being the coolest months. The area lies on the fringe of the monsoon belt, with more than 70 percent of the rain falling during the monsoon period from June to September. Average annual rainfall ranges from about 650 mm (Lahore) to 190 nmm (Bahawalnagar), generally decreasing from the north-east to the south-west(Annex 1, Table 3). Conversely, the annual reference evapotranspiration (ET() ranges from about 1,650 mm in Lahore to 1,880 mm in Bahawalnagar. 2.3 The soils have been formed from alluvium derived from the mountain ranges to the north and deposited by the present and ancestral rivers of the Indus basin. (Annex 1, Table 4). Water Resources 2.4 Surface Water Supplies. The Indus River and its four major tributaries (Jhelum, Chenab, Ravi and Sutlej) flow through the Punjab. Water from these rivers is diverted by a series of barrages into 9 large canal systems serving the project area. River flows are highly seasonal with almost 60 percent of the total annual flow occurring between June and August. Yearly variations in surface water diversions to the canals are reducing over time, mainly due to increasing control over the river system by reservoirs, inter-river link canals and barrages. In the fresh groundwater areas of the project, the average canal water supply at the watercourse head from 1988-1992 was 3.51 million acre feet (4,325 million m3) and accounted for 41 percent of total irrigation supplies. In saline groundwater areas, the surface water supply averaged 0.86 million acre feet (1,063 million m3), equivalent to 69 Percent of total irrigation supplies. Surface water supplies are also the main source of recharge to the groundwater which is then reused by pumping through tubewells. 2.5 Groundwater Supplies. A total of 5,054 STWs were installed in the project area, of which 4,233 were in the fresh groundwater areas and the remaining 821 in the saline areas. In FGW areas about 90 percent of fresh groundwater STWs (3,860) are currently operational but only 15 percent are in good condition, capable of pumping 80 percent or more of their original capacity (Annex 1, Table 9). The present capacity of the STWs is estimated at 9,597 cusecs (272 m3 per second) supplying about 2.32 million acre feet (2,867 million m3) of irrigation water at the watercourse heads. Pumping groundwater at the head of the watercourse improves overall distribution as well as application efficiency, including that of canal water. In most watercourses the canal water does not reach towards the tail when the STW is not operating. Therefore, tail farmers lose their share of canal water and they are left with the option of using PTW water only. The use of groundwater without canal water leads to damaging of the soils. In saline areas of SCARP II, about 426 have marginal quality water useable only after mixing with the canal water. These tubewells pump water into the watercourses while the remaining tubewells having water supply unsafe for irrigation use, discharge water into canals (119 STWs ) and drains. Total pumpage in the saline area of SCARP II is estimated at 0.25 million acre-feet (308 million m3). 2.6 In addition, low capacity (typically 0.75 to 1 cusec) PTWs have been installed where fresh or marginal groundwater can be obtained from shallow aquifer, usually to a depth of 30 meters. There are about 44,000 PTWs in the fresh groundwater project areas pumping 3.01 million acre-feet (3,710 million m3). Their utilization rate of PTWs is extremely low compared with STWs --below 10 percent. In addition, there are 1,780 PTWs in the saline zones of SCARPs II that have pockets of marginally fresh groundwater. These PTWs pump about 0.13 million acre-feet (162 million m3). The project works require relatively simple engineering designs for watercourse improvements and canal lining, that are prepared routinely by PID, OFWM in close cooperation with farmners. Similarly. farmers in Punjab have considerable experience in installing as well as operating and maintaining tubewells. Drilling facilities. tubewell equipment (pumps, prime movers, screens, pipes, etc.) and repair workshops are available locally at the village level in most areas. Water Availability 6.2 The condition and effectiveness of STWs would continue to decline, as it has been in the past, and their delivery of water would likely fall to virtually nothinig over the next ten years. In the fresh groundwater areas this would mean an overall reduction in irrigation supplies by about 26 percent. BENEFITS, JUSTIFICATION AND RISKS A. Benefits and Justification Quantified Benefits 7. 1 As described in the preceding chapter (para 6.2 to 6.4), in the future without the project the PTWs are expected to replace the pumpage of STWs as these become derelict. The project would generate benefits through installation of CTWs which are a lower cost alternative to the operation of PTWs (Annex 10, Table 2). Although there is a likelihood that agricultural production would decline with the closure of STWs, the benefits due to avoiding this loss with the project have not been quantified. However, the benefits due to increased agricultural production with watercourses and canals improvements in fresh and saline groundwater areas have been quantified. The project benefit streams, therefore, include: (a) the benefits due to reduction in pumping costs --CTWs instead of PTWs; and (b) the benefits due to increased agricultural production from increased water supply with system improvements in fresh and saline groundwater areas. The benefits due to reduction in waterlogging and salinity with measures under the Prevention of Saline Groundwater Intrusion component, as well as with the development of a groundwater regulatory framework, and benefits of pilot projects and training under the Technical Assistance component are not included. 7.2 The analysis based on these conservative assumptions shows that the project would generate substantial economic benefits in the short- and long-term. The cost of pumping groundwater with STWs is about Rs. 685 million (pumping about 2.32 MAF of groundwater in June 1995 economic prices). By closing the STWs and replacing the same pumpage with PTWs the cost of pumping would
 - 44 - reduce by Rs. 114 million. With the project, assuming 75 percent participation in the CTW program, the cost of pumping would reduce further by Rs. 174 million at full development. The returns to closing the STWs are extremely high and even greater by replacing those with CTWs. With surface system improvements, the value of production would increase by about Rs. 883.4 million (Annex 11, Table 6). The project would directly benefit some 380,000 farm families, particularly the 80 percent with small farms. On-farm employment would increase slightly, by about 3 percent in situations with CTWs only and about 15 percent with CTWs and surface improvements. Other Benefits 7.3 The project would also generate substantial environmental and other benefits. The high capital investment required to set up PTWs and anarchic development of groundwater would be avoided. The increased availability of electricity resulting from the shut down of STWs would also contribute to overcoming some of the chronic electricity shortages in the country. It would encourage the participatory irrigation management and development of FOs; and would lead to forming sustainable participation of farmers at the higher level of the canal system. The introduction of groundwater regulations would promote and guide private investments, and ensure environmentally sustainable exploitation of groundwater. CTWs would improve the distribution of ground and surface water. Since CTWs are easier to nmonitor and have self-regulating characteristics, costs of monitoring and regulation would be lower. Finally, privatization of highly inefficient STWs would substantially reduce the O&M burden on the Government. This would allow to re-direct resources to improve O&M of canals and drainage systems, as well as increase investments in activities where the private sector cannot take a lead, such as off-farm drainage, large canals and inter-river transfer facilities. B. Economic Analysis 7.4 The economic viability of the project has been tested through estimation of an economic rate of return (ERR). The economic value of project benefits has been calculated by evaluating incremental outputs and inputs at economic prices and, in the case of non-traded commodities, by using a standard conversion factor (SCF) of 0.9 (Annex 10, Tables I and 2). Economic costs have been calculated from total project costs, including physical contingencies, with the local cost component being adjusted by the SCF and excluding taxes and duties. 7.5 The ERR for the CTWs component is estimated at 19 percent, for the surface improvements component the ERR is 26 percent and for the overall project 24 percent (Annex 11, Tables 7),3 As explained above, the returns on the CTWs component are due to reduction in operating and capital cost of CTWs compared with PTWs having low utilization rates. The returns on the surface improvements, are due to increased water supply and improved conjunctive use of surface and groundwater resulting in increased agricultural production. C. D. Risks and Sensitivity Analysis Project Risks 7.10 There are three main risks to the project. Firstly, lower participation by the farmers lxcause: (a' farmers may prefer to have their own PTWs; (b) the public tubewells are a source of cheap it rigation water for many farmers, who may, especially the influential ones, pressure the Government to stop or delay their closure; and (c) the PID staff which is presently engaged in the O&M of STWs would become redundant with the divestment of public tubewells and may try to retard the project progress. This risk would be minimized by: (a) launchiiig an extensive social mobilization program for demonstrating to the farmers the benefits of participatory irrigation management, and for developing effective FOs; (b, providing incentives for installation of CTWs; and (c) assigning the responsibility of privatization of tubewells to the PMU and by providing a training program and severance package for redeployinent of PID staff. The sensitivity analysis, based on the above risks, shows that it is highly unlikely that unfavorable developments would reduce the project ERR to opportunity cost of capital (OCC) --taken as 12 percent. Even if the participation is only half of the anticipated level (37 percent), ERR of CTW component would be equal to OCC while overall project ERR would be about 17 percent (Annex II Table 7b). The benefits from surface system improvements would have to fall by more than 60 percent for ERR to decline to OCC. Alternately, ERR would be equal to OCC if costs increase by about 100 percent. ERR response to different combinations of changes in costs and benefits ranging from -50 to 50 percent is shown in Annex 11, Figure 1. Annex 11, Figure 2 shows combinations of changes in overall costs and benefits where ERR would switch from being acceptable to falling below the OCC. A few points fi-om this curve are given in Table 7. 1. It shows that if costs uniformly increase by 20 percent, the project's performance would still be satisfactory as long as the reduction in benefits is less than 40 percent. Delays of one or two years in realizing benefits are not expected to affect the project's performance significantly.  Annex 3 -69- Page I of 12 PAKISTAN Punjab Private Sector Groundwater Development Project Terms of Reference For Project Implementation Assistance Consultants 1. INTRODUCTION 1. The Government of Pakistan (GOP) has requested the International Development Association (IDA) for a Credit to meet part of the cost of the proposed Punjab Private Sector Groundwater Development. The project is being implemented by the Government of Punjab (GOPunjab). A Project Management Unit (PMU) in the Planning & Development Board of GOPunjab is responsible for overall project management and coordination. The Punjab Irrigation Department (PID) and the Directorate General of Water Management (OFWM) in the Agricultural Departments are the co-implementing agencies. These terms of reference are for consultancy services in various fields for providing implementation assistance to the PMU, PID, and OFWM. 2. Project Objectives. The overall objectives of the PGWD Project are to increase the scope and productivity of Punjab's irrigation and drainage subsector and increase farmer's incomes. Its specific objectives are to: (a) redefine govemment's role in groundwater development with a greater role for the private sector; (b) develop a regulatory framework and a monitoring program to ensure sustainable use of the groundwater resources; (c) develop sustainable farmers organizations (FOs) which can efficiently operate and maintain groundwater irrigation, improve surface irrigation, and establish a base for participation in the management of the canal systems; (d) rationalize public expenditure on O&M of the irrigation and drainage systems as well as increase the recovery of public expenditures on irrigation infrastructure; and (e) avoid environmental hazard of saline water intrusion into fresh groundwater aquifers. 3. Project Description. The proposed five-year (FY97-2001) project would cover the fresh groundwater areas (FGW) of SCARP 11 (including Shahpur), SCARP III (Rangpur Unit), SCARP IV and SCARP V (Shorkot Kamnalia) located in administrative divisions of Sargodha, Gujranwala, Faisalabad, and Lahore. It also includes saline groundwater (SGWs) areas within or at the boundaries of FGW areas. The gross area is about 1.455 million ha of which about 1.193 million ha have FGW, while the CCA is about 1.292 million hectares of which about 1.068 million hectares have FGW. The major project components are: (a) privatization of SCARP tubewells (STWs); (b) development of groundwater monitoring and regulatory framework; (c) improvement of irrigation facilities in fresh groundwater areas, including improvement of watercourses and lining of minor canals; (d) prevention of saline groundwater intrusion into fresh aquifers, including rehabilitation of drainage tubewells, and lining of watercourses in saline groundwater areas; (e) monitoring and evaluation; (f) technical assistance and training; (g) project management and supervision.
 Annex 3 -70- Page 2 of 12 II. SCOPE OF CONSULTING SERVICES 4. The project requires multi-/interdisciplinary consultancy services in the following four categories: A. Project management support; B. Community mobilization and formation of farmer organizations (FOs) for privatizing STWs, and promoting farmer participation in canal lining; C. Engineering services for surveys, design and construction supervision of civil works (canal lining, watercourse improvement, and rehabilitation of drainage tubewells), including role of the "Engineer" in contract management; and D. Preparation of groundwater regulatory framework. A. Project Management Support 5. This includes assistance to the Project Director (PD) PMU and other core staff of the PMU for, inter alia: (i) procurement planning and processing and ensuring compliance with IDA procurement guidelines at all stages (receipt of bids, evaluation and award of contracts); (ii) maintenance of consolidated project accounts and arranging for timely annual audits; (iii) preparation of consolidated annual work plans for all project components; (iv) preparation of annual budgetary requests; (v) establishment of an MIS, and preparation of periodic progress reports and project implementation completion report; (vi) preparation and implementation of training programs; and (vii) preparation of project supervision plans for the P&D Board. These services would be provided by the Project Manager of the consultants with inputs of MIS and Accounting and Financial Management Specialists and support staff. Total input is estimated at 60 staff months (SMs). B. Community Mobilization for Divestment of SCARP tubewells and Canal Lining 6. The proposed project will privatize approximately 4,200 SCARP tubewells (STWs)'. The project will support the formation of FOs, and, through them, the establishment of privately operated community tubewells (CTWs) to replace govemment-operated STWs throughout the project area. The objective of this project activity is to develop FOs that can efficiently operate and maintain surface and groundwater resources for irrigated agriculture in Punjab on a sustainable basis. To achieve this objective, the project will support the development of a social mobilization program within the Project Management Unit (PMU). The PMU will have overall responsibility for the project's social mobilization efforts through a Community Development Support Group (CDSG) recruited as consultancy services. The CDSG team will consist of: (a) core staff responsible for CDSG field staff training and management, and social mobilization program coordination; and (b) field staff of Social Organizers (SOs) working with the help of NGOs and village level social activists to mobilize farmer participation in project activities. CDSG will have responsibility for the privatization of approximately 2,700, or two-thirds of the STWs targeted for privatization. The CDSG will also be responsible for assisting the PID in promoting farmer participation in canal lining, and watch and ward as well as operation and maintenance (O&M) of Of which 2,458 STWs are located in SCARPs II and Shahpur, 1,001 in SCARP IV, 570 in SCARP III (Rangpur unit), and 101 in SCARP V.
 -71- Annex 3 Page 3 of 12 drainage tubewell rehabilitated under the project. The Directorate of OFWM will be responsible for privatizing the remaining 1,500 STWs in conjunction with a program of project-supported watercourse improvement. The PMU will have the overall responsibility for coordination and supervision of all STW privatization and FO development activities supported by the project, including those undertaken by OFWM. 7. The CDSG will report to the PD PMU through the Director (Project Management and Community Development) of the PMU. It will comprise of international and national consultants and provide management, technical and implementation services in support of the project's social mobilization program. The consultancy team will undertake two interrelated activities: (a) to assist the PMU in the management and coordination of the project's social mobilization efforts, including the training and supervision of field-level technical and support staff, and coordination of field activities with those of OFWM; and (b) to mobilize farmer participation in the privatization of STWs, and in the improved management of surface and groundwater resources. The CDSG will also be responsible for engaging local Non Governmental Organizations (NGOs) for mobilizing farmer participation in the project. 8. Management, Coordination and Training Activities. A core group of consultants within the CDSG will provide management, coordination and training services for the social mobilization program of the project. This core group will: a. develop and field test a standardized model for the formation of FOs, and ensure its adoption by all agencies involved in the project's social mobilization efforts (i.e., consultants, NGOs and OFWM)2; b. develop and implement a comprehensive training program for all social mobilization field staff in the principles of participatory community development, and in appropriate methods for mobilizing farmer participation in FOs; c. design and supervise Watercourse Assessment Surveys to be carried out over the entire project area to collect baseline data on socio-economic, agronomic, hydrological and infrastructure conditions prevailing in the watercourse CCA served by each STW targeted for transition; d. prepare coordinated and detailed annual work plans for the deployment of CDSG field staff throughout the project area, and the achievement of STW transition and FO formation targets; e. provide regular supervision to all CDSG field staff during the initial phases of project implementation, and provide on-going guidance to the project's supervisory Social Coordinators in the management of the field personnel under their supervision; f. in coordination with the PMU, develop standardized project monitoring and evaluation procedures and general reporting formats for documenting project performance; g. develop a set of criteria for the monitoring and evaluation of project impact in building sustainable FOs that can be integrated into the overall project MIS. 2 The model developed under the Second SCARP Transition Project would be used as a starting point and further refinements would be made.
 -72- Annex 3 Page 4 of 12 9. Social Mobilization Activities. The main objective of these activities is to establish viable FOs that would install and subsequently operate and maintain CTWs. FOs would have the option to: (i) takeover the SCARP tubewells as such and operate them as community tubewell (CTWs); (ii) modify STWs and run them as CTW; (iii) install new CTWs; or (iv) replace the STWs' pumpage with existing or new private tubewells (PTWs). A growing body of evidence indicates that the privatization of public tubewells supplying irrigation water provides farmers with better control over the joint use of surface and groundwater resources. Improved control over these resources results in improved irrigation efficiencies and increased agricultural productivity.4 When privatization strategies are designed to promote the organization of farmers for the joint-ownership of pump irrigation schemes, improvements in the equity of irrigation water distribution are more or less guaranteed. Joint-ownership leads to better management of both surface and sub-surface water resources, establishes a foundation for the regulation of groundwater extraction (through cooperative management) and sets the precedent , through the strengthening of participatory management processes, for greater farmer involvement in increasingly more complex levels of resource management.... 2. The proposed project would transfer the ownership of approximately 4,200 public tubewells -- installed in the 1960s and 1970s under successive Salinization Control and Reclamation Projects (SCARPs) -- to farmer groups in four SCARP regions of Punjab Province. The project will support the formation of approximately 6,300 Farmer Organizations (FOs) and their development of privately operated community tubewells (CTWs) to replace govemment-operated SCARP tubewells (STWs) throughout the project area. The objective of the project's farmer participation plan is to develop FOs that can efficiently operate and maintain surface and groundwater resources for irrigated agriculture in Punjab on a sustainable basis. 3. Central to the success of public tubewell (STW) privatization would be the project's promotion of farmer participation in the development and management of private groundwater extraction, i.e., in the collective investment in community tubewells, the operation and maintenance of those tubewells, and the effective and sustainable use of groundwater resources in conjunction with surface water supplies. The encouragement of CTW development is necessary to ensure that all farmers retain access to sufficient supplies of groundwater to augment surface supplies when STWs are taken out of operation. In addition, the project's successful promotion of CTW operation would to enhance the equity of water resource distribution by improving water supplies to farmers with small land holdings at the tailend of the tertiary conveyance systems. 4. The promotion of sustainable FOs and their operation of CTWs will require an intensive institutional development effort. Evaluation of past and disappointing experiences in the promotion of Water Users Associations for the improvement and maintenance of surface water conveyance systems in Pakistan indicates that: (i) beneficiaries were not given sufficient autonomy in the planning, participation and management of the watercourse improvements; (ii) the implementing agencies lacked the required skills to build effective Associations; (iii) the amount of resources required to support sustainable Associations, particularly in terms of institution building and follow-up visits by field staff, were vastly underestimated; and (iv) incentives for farmer participation in the Associations were short-lived.  Annex 4 -83- Page 3 of 17 Rationale for a Participatory Approach 8. Community participation in rural development involves beneficiaries in the identification, design, financing and implementation of their own development projects. Community participation directly supports projects suited to the needs and abilities of the people whom the projects are intended to benefit. In contrast, conventional approaches involving donor-to-government development grant or loan assistance typically seek to strengthen the capacity of host-country institutions to deliver assistance. Conventional projects are typically identified by outsiders (project managers, government officials, technical experts) or project committees made up of local notables who represent their community to outsiders. Neither of these groups is bound by community preference in the selection of projects. As a result, conventional projects often fall short of providing the intended benefits to the community. Not surprisingly, there is little incentive for the community to support or participate in a project that it did not request and that may not serve its needs. 9. The impact of participatory approaches has been particularly well documented in the irrigation sector.7 Since the 1950s, large amounts of money have been invested to improve irrigated agriculture worldwide. While initial investments in infrastructure contributed to a significant expansion of food production, a growing share of investments in the irrigation sector over the past 20 years have been targeted for the rehabilitation of irrigation infrastructure that the governments and water users have failed to maintain. With fiscal crises in most developing countries, weaknesses of government delivery of water services have become apparent. The deterioration of irrigation systems throughout the world has exposed serious institutional deficiencies and resulting government failures in most water resources agencies. This includes lack of motivation and accountability of agency staff, high levels of political interference and rent seeking, as well as inadequate concern for needs of users. Consequently, without reliable service, users are not willing to share in the investment, operation and maintenance costs. Reliance on overextended government agencies that have neglected financial accountability, user participation, and charging while not delivering services effectively to the users and particularly to the poor is a major concern. The Bank's review of twenty-one irrigation projects found meaningful cost recovery only in those projects in which water management and O&M had been entrusted to water users. 10. Because of their limited financial and administrative resources, governments need to be selective in the responsibility they assume for water resources. An operational principle is that nothing should be done at a higher level of government that can be done satisfactorily at a lower level. Thus, where local or private capabilities exist the water delivery service should be transferred to private sector, financially autonomous public corporations, and to community organizations. The lessons of experience suggest that an important principle in restructuring public service agencies is their conversion into financially autonomous entities, with effective authority to charge and collect fees and with freedom to manage without political interference. Such entities need to work under hard budget constraint that enhances incentives for efficiency and revenue generation. Participation empowers stakeholder to influence the formulation of policy, the choice of design and investment, an management decision affecting their communities. The participatory development approach in Pakistan is characterized by the organization of small farmiers into decentralized, broad-based and homogeneous interest groups called Village Organizations (VO). The approach has its origins in the small farmer development initiatives conceived during the cooperative movement of the 1970s. These included the Comila Project in what is now Bangladesh and the Daudzai Project near Peshawar implemented by the Pakistan Academy of Rural Development. The approach assumes that villagers with relatively homogeneous resources, who own their crop land, and who collectively manage the distribution of public resources such as irrigation water and common grazing land, will cooperate to finance, manage, and maintain village-level infrastructure projects that benefit all villagers. As the approach has evolved, in the context of donor-supported rural development initiatives, local communities establish their own institutions, identify their development priorities, organize their resources, manage their development agenda, and create the necessary links for continuing technical and financial assistance by outside agencies. The supporting agency -- either governmental or nongovernmental -- provides technical and financial assistance, but it does not infringe on the autonomy of the village organization. Decision-making rests with the community, which can reject the advice and judgement of the project experts." 22. The Transition from Public to Private Development of Groundwater Resources 32. Over the last three decades, approximately 13,500 public tubewells have been installed by the Government of Pakistan to control waterlogging and saline soil conditions throughout the irrigated areas of the Indus River Basin under a succession of Salinity Control and Reclamation Projects (SCARP). Nearly 75 percent of these tubewells were installed in Punjab Province. In saline groundwater areas, SCARP tubewells pumped water into surface drains or main canals. In fresh groundwater areas, water from STWs was normally pumped into tertiary watercourses and used to augment surface irrigation water supplies. The SCARP projects were generally successful in meeting the objectives of controlling the depth of water tables and supplementing surface irrigation water supplies. However, STW performance has declined over tine due to poor management, political interference and inadequate funding for O&M. Half of all STWs in Punjab operate at below 50 percent capacity, and only 15 percent operate at better than 80 percent capacity. 33. Poor STW performance has in a number of areas been compensated by informal farmers groups that have formed spontaneously. However, farmers find it difficult to carry out repairs involving the main shaft of the turbine because such repairs require specialized equipment available only with Punjab Irrigation Department (PID) workshops. Nevertheless, farmers follow-up and assist PID in expediting such repairs. 34. From the review of farmer participation in Pakistan, and specifically in the irrigation sector, the following lessons can be drawn: (a) The conjunctive use of surface and groundwater resources improves irrigation efficiencies and the equity of resource distribution. (b) In comparison with public and private (individual) systems of pump irrigation, inigation efficiencies and equity of water distribution improve when farming communities collaborate to operate and maintain tubewells and the conjunctive use of surface and groundwater resources. (c) The sustainability of farmer organizations is directly proportional to the extent that they are organized around productive investment and they have true control over the management of those resources to maximize return on the investment. (d) The formation of enduring farmer organizations requires continuous support at the social as well as the technical level to ensure that the organization endures potential social, economic and political conflicts that discourage collective action. (e) Under current circumstances in Punjab, consultants are likely to provide the best level of support to FOs. Government departments do not have the capacity or experience to support FOs, and ingrained procedures prevent government bureaucracies from readily adapting to what has been considered more effective procedures. (f) NGO capacity in Punjab is oriented towards the promotion of social welfare and not participatory rural development. However, the their social activism and familiarity with rural social relations can be tapped and used effectively when consultants provide capacity building and administrative support to NGO staff. 45. These lessons have been incorporated into the proposed plan for farmer participation in the proposed Project described in the following section. Farmer Participation Under the Project 46. The Institutional Framework. The proposed project aims to convert approximately 4,200 STWs in four SCARP regions of Punjab Province over a period of five years. The project will support the formation of approximately 6,300 village-level Farmer Organizations (FOs) and their development of privately operated community tubewells (CTWs) to replace government-operated STWs throughout the project area. The objective of this project activity is to develop FOs that can efficiently operate and maintain surface and groundwater resources for irrigated agriculture in Punjab on a sustainable basis. The achievement of this objective will require considerable human and financial resources. A grass roots effort of this type requires an organization with specific skills and experience in social mobilization and a network of local level contacts. The Bank's pre-appraisal mission explored the possibility of using NGOs to assume responsibility for managing the social mobilization aspects of the project. However, it was mission's assessment that NGO capacity in Punjab is too limited to handle the extensive task. Therefore, the preferred alternative is to establish an institutional framework consisting of a Project Management Unit (PMU); social mobilization consultants and local level NGOs with the participation of PAD and PID.

 Annex 5 -93- Page I of 5 PAKISTAN Punjab Private Sector Groundwater Development Project Groundwater Management and Regulation L. BACKGROUND Agriculture is the main economic base of Pakistan. Because of climatic conditions irrigatioii is essential for sustained agricultural production. Even though irrigation has existed for centuries. the relatively recent expansion of surface water delivery systems has resulted in significant hydrological changes. The additional supplies of surface water to the irrigated land without appropriate drainage facilities has resulted in increased groundwater levels causing either waterlogged areas or saline intrusioni or both. The Salinity Control and Reclamation Projects (SCARP) were commenced in the 1960's to conitrol waterlogginig and salinity in irrigated areas. Large size tubewells operated and maintained by the Government were installed under these projects. While the SCARP tubewells were largely successful in controlling waterlogging and salinity their performance declined due to lack of funds for O&M and poor management. In addition to drainage, tubewells in fresh groundwater area provide substantial irrigation supplies, supplementing the canal water. Because the farmers saw the viability and advantages of groundwater development, a very large number of private tubewells (PTW) have been installed. This had the affect of lowering groundwater levels, and in some locations, encouraging saline water intrision inito fresh water zones. There are several reasons for excessive pumpage from grounidwater. Due to inequitable distribution of surface supplies in some areas groundwater is the only source for irrigation specifically towards the tails of the surface systems. Lack of knowledge about crop water requirements and the use of flat rate charges for electricity are also contributing factors to the overdraft. 2. The groundwater records indicate that the water tables in fresh areas in general are falling slowly. This coupled with the continued proliferation of PTWs could potentially damage the groundwater aquifers. A plan for managinig the groundwater resources should be considered at this stage to avoid problems whiich could arise due unregulated development. Therefore, as a part of the project, a groundwater management plan applicable to all aquifers in Punjab would be developed. This annex provides an outlile of methodology for developing groundwater management and regulation and plan for its implementation. 11. EXISTING LEGISLATION & REGULATIONS I. Punjab Soil Reclamation Act, 1952 Applicable Provisions defines tube-well as "well worked with electric or thermal power to draw out sub-soil water" (Chapter I para 2). authorizes the Board, to prevent waterlogging and salinity, "to provide for the installation, management and maintenance of tubewells and disposal of underground water by other means"; "the draining of villages and land"; "replacement of canal water supply by

(Chapter IV, para 17). "As soon as a scheme ... is sanctioned as notified ... the use of underground waters in that area except the water used for domestic purposes or for watering livestock shall come Linder control of the Board". (Chapter IV, para 26). In the area for whichi the scheme has been sanctioned the Board may order any tubewell for using groundwater, to be closed down either temporarily during specified period of the year or permanently, provided that such shall order not prohibit use of underground waters by any owner or occupier of land for domestic purposes and for watering livestock. For the improvement, reclamation and lowering of sub-soil water table in any local area... the Board may - direct in respect to any area - the permitting by the owners and occupiers of setting tubewells and borings and use of water therefrom in place of that canal". (Chapter V, para 28) Discussion Although the main objective of the Soil Reclamation Act at the time of its enactment was controlling waterlogging and salinity, the Act has provision for controlling the groundwater use when such use has adverse effect on the resources. T he Punjab Government issues a series of rules (1965) for safe exploitation of groundwater aquifers. These rules included requirement for a license for installing tubewells in the areas declared as project by the Government, procedures and forms for obtaining license, and established license fees. Powers of the Board changed from time to time. The executive powers are now exercised by the Secretary, Irrigation and Power Development (effective January 3 1, 1973). T here is no evidence that the Rule above was ever implemented. 2. West Pakistan Water and Power Development Authority, Act 1958. Applicable Provisions - "subject to the provision of any other law for the time being in force, the Authority --shall have control over the underground water resources of any regime in West Pakistan" (para 11). - "before the Authority exercises control ... the area over which and the extent to which and the extent to which control is intended to be exercised shall be agreed to and notified by the Government in the official Gazette" (para I I). Discussion No evidence of any issuing of required rules. WAPDA is a Federal agency and since the Pakistan Constitution reserves the control over water to the Provinces there is some question as to the actual authority of WAPDA to regulate groundwater.

Discussion: No known regulation or enforcement. Related Matters 4. The Preamble to the WAPDA Act provides for the unified and coordinated development of the water and power resources of Pakistan. It also extends WAPDA's control over the groundwater aquifers, however, this control is in the context of controlling waterlogging and salinity. In accordance with the Preamble WAPDA collects, analyzes and publishes surface and groundwater data. Although water quality data collection is now limited to SCARP areas with increased staff the program could cover the whole country. WAPDA also collects climatology data nationally. Conclusions 5. Neither the Government of Pakistan nor any Provincial Government has undertaken groundwater regulation except for spacing of wells in SCARP areas. The control provisions in WAPDA Act may be limited by the Constitutional provision of water being the subject of Provinces. The Soil Reclamation Act of 1952 with its amendments appears to be most specific legislation about controlling installation of tubewells where these have ill effects oii the resources. 6. In any event WAPDA would be responsible for overall monitoring of the basins' surface and groundwater resource, inter-provincial transfers of surface, ground and drainage waters. Even though WAPDA could perhaps be designated as the groundwater regulating agency with some relatively minor legal changes, a conflict could arise between the development arm of WAPDA and the regulatory element which is better suited for provincial and local Governments. Therefore, separate institutional setup with representative of the Govermnent and water users or Farmers' Organizations should be considered for enforcing groundwater regulations. In addition regulatory framework should have a mechanism for self- management at the local level. The detailed institutional structure for implementation of regulations would be developed during the project as part of the groundwater regulatory program. III. DEVELOPMENT OF REGULATORY FRAMEWORK 7. No work has been done in Pakistan about developing a regulatory framework to manage the groundwater aquifer with falling water tables. This is due to the reason that until now rising and not falling water tables were the major problem affecting the agricultural production. Considerable amount of data gathering, modelling and analysis is needed before starting the enforcement of regulations controlling the groundwater use. The program of developing regulation and their implementation would consist of three phases; (i) in the first phase, the groundwater management areas will be established based on the existing information ; (ii) in the second phase critical areas for groundwater management would be identified, detailed data collection and monitoring would be carried out in the critical areas, and safe yields of aquifers and groundwater rights would be determined; (iii) in the third phase a procedure for
 -101- Annex 5 Page 4 of 5 regulating the groundwater use in each critical areas, and institutional structure would be developed. 8. Establishment of Management Areas. For ease in management of the groundwater basins the groundwater aquifers in Punjab will be divided into different Groundwater Management areas, based on existing data, and considering behavior and quality of groundwater aquifers, hydrological and meteorological data, topographic and geological information, canal command areas, surface water application, efficiency of use, and cropping patterns, etc. During this phase a database consisting of basic information for each management areas would also be developed which will be updated on a continuous basis. The sources of major aquifer recharge as well as extractions will be identified in each management area. This phase would be completed in a period of one year. 9. Establishing Critical Areas and Groundwater Rights. In parallel to establishing the Groundwater Management areas, the critical areas requiring extensive management would be identified. The groundwater models would be developed, and calibrated to simulate the groundwater behavior over a long period including wet and dry cycles. Using the simulation models and monitoring information, rights to the groundwater will be established by distributary command area, watercourse command (chak) and by farm. Detailed data collection will be carried out for calibration of the model, and developing a database for eventual regulation of groundwater use for the critical areas. This phase will be completed by the second year of the project. 10. Procedures for Regulation and Institutional Structure. In preparing the groundwater regulation procedure the emphasis would be given to simple rules, and self regulating systems tested around some pilot operations. Basing on the safe yields of the aquifer in the long run (considering wet and dry cycles), pattern of groundwater water use in the critical areas, utilization rates of private, community and public tubewells, estimates will be made for safe installed capacity by watercourse command, as well as by distributaries. For foreseeable future the regulation will be based on the installed capacity of the tubewells which will be correlated to the actual groundwater extractions through empirical studies and simulation models. A program for licensing the groundwater tubewells with an objective towards achieving safe installed capacity will be instituted. In issuing the tubewell licenses preference will be give to community tubewells supplying to several users in chak. The detailed institutional setup for groundwater management in each management area will vary depending upon the type and the severity of the problem. Overall responsibility for regulation of groundwater would be given to an independent body. This phase would be completed in third project year. 11. Pilots for Groundwater Management. As part of developing effective groundwater regulation strategy a few pilots would be implemented before refining the regulation procedures. The objectives of the pilots would be to test and evolve most effective methods for groundwater management, assessment of the extent of regulation required, effectiveness of allocation and distribution of groundwater rights, and roles of the regulating and monitoring agencies, surface water and drainage agencies, the farmers and their organizations, local governments and NGOs in implementation of the groundwater regulations. 12. Implementation. The implementation strategy for groundwater management would depend on the type of groundwater problem in each management area. In areas where water table is still rising, installation of community tubewells will be encouraged by forming effective FOs through social mobilization programs, dissemination of the groundwater monitoring information to FOs and teaching effective water conservation measures to reduce the surface water losses to the groundwater. In areas with marginal quality groundwater, techniques of improved conjunctive use and saline irrigation would be disseminated to the FOs. A complete solution would be developed in such areas as the capability of the

In areas where a balance have been achieved or water tables are falling, a program of licensing the groundwater tubewells will be started during the last two years of the project. At the same time, suitable mechanisms for increasing the recharge to the fresh groundwater aquifers would be investigated. A comprehensive public information program would be developed outlining the current groundwater situation and consequences if the present situation continues. Forming FOs would be a condition for issuing tubewell licenses. For these areas a local as well as umbrella regulating agency would be developed. Other important elements of regulation would include, development of self- regulating systems, and regulation of drilling operations. 14. Self Regulating Systems. The best way to a create suitable environment for the development self regulating system is to install community tubewells (CTWs) instead of individually owned tubewells. With CTWs excessive installation could be avoided, taking better advantage of conjunctive surface and groundwater use, and pumpage would be regulated by the availability and the capacity of the surface system itself. In order to make the system fully self regulating the FOs should be large enough so that over pumping or saline water intrusion has a direct impact on their cost of operation. This would be a longer term objective and it has to be achieved through reforms in the surface water distribution systems, where canal command level management would be entrusted to the Public Utilities and effective FOs would be developed to management the O&M of the distributary systems. 15. Drilling Operations. Licensing drillers could include a testing of the driller's knowledge of tubewell drilling, requirements of regulatory agency and groundwater protection. To begin with as an alternative to licensing the drillers, regulating agency would maintain a register of drillers in the management area. In the longer run, however, the drillers would have to be licensed. In any event, drillers would be required to provide certain information (depth, formations, depth to water, water samples, etc.) to the regulatory agency for the continuing purpose of evaluating the groundwater basins. 16. Permit to Install tubewell. A permit to drill could be accommodated before the drilling operation phase and a permit to withdraw handled later. However, in most cases a water user would accomplish both prior to drilling. Permits could be conditioned on discharge capacity limits, depth to water limit, size of casing, size of pump, and type electric or diesel. However, with the possibility of self- regulation the FOR may want the individual users to measure or estimate pumping (keeping logbooks, measuring drawdown, etc.).
