Annual summary reports; f. special reports as may be necessary from time to time on specific assignments; g. a preliminary project impact evaluation report to be issued before the Credit Closing date. III. IMPLEMENTATION ARRANGEMENTS 9. A Project Management Unit (PMU) in the Punjab Planning and Development Board is responsible for coordinating overall project implementation, and directly implementing some of the project components. The PMU is composed of a full time Project Director (PD), two ex-officio Members (one each from the Irrigation Department and the Directorate General of Water Management), and three Directors as well as support staff. The PMU would be supported by the PIA consultants for whose The short-listed consultants should submit their own estimates of staff inputs and team composition.

The PMU is responsible for: (a) overall project management and coordination; (b) development of groundwater regulatory framework; (c) community development for formation of FOs and establishment of CTWs, including processing and disbursement of financial assistance to FOs; (d) project performance monitoring & evaluation, including development of an MIS system; (e) impact evaluation studies; (f) planning, budgeting, maintenance of consolidated project accounts, and ensuring timely submission of audit reports; (g) procurement of vehicles and all consulting services required for the project. 10. The PID through the Member (Irrigation) of PMU, is responsible for STWs closures and retrieval of machinery from the bore holes and their capping, canal rehabilitation/lining, drainage rehabilitation and O&M contracts, and re-deployment of redundant staff. I I. The Directorate General of Water Management is responsible for improving watercourses, and establishing FOs and CTWs in designated areas. Area and field teams would be established for this purpose. The Member (Water Management) would, inter alia, be responsible for (i) ensuring close coordination between the PMU and the Directorate General of Water Management. 12. The PMU will sign the contract with the selected PIE consultants and hold responsibility for all matters relating to the management of this contract. The Team Leader of the PIE consultants will report to the PD PMU through the Director (Regulation) who is responsible for monitoring and evaluation. The consultants will also report to the Members for (Irrigation) and (Water Management) for providing PIE feed back relating to canal lining and watercourse improvement and community mobilization aspects.

 -125- Annex 9 Page I of 14 PAKISTAN Punjab Private Sector Groundwater Development Project Project Implementation Plan A. The Project The overall project objectives are to increase the scope and productivity of Punjab's irrigation and drainage subsector and increase farmers' incomes. Its specific objectives are to: (a) redefine government's role in groundwater development and provide assistance to facilitate change; (b) develop a monitoring program and regulatory framework to ensure sustainable use of the groundwater resources; (c) develop sustainable farmers' organizations (FOs) which can efficiently operate and maintain groundwater irrigation, improve surface irrigation and establish a base for participation in the management of the canal systems; (d) increase beneficiaries' incomes and alleviate poverty; (e) rationalize public expenditure on O&M of the irrigation and drainage systems as well as increase the recovery of public expenditures on irrigation infrastructure; and (f) avoid environmental hazard of saline water intrusion into fresh groundwater aquifers. 2. The major project components are: (a) privatization of SCARP tubewells; (b) development of a groundwater monitoring and regulatory framework; (c) improvement of irrigation conveyance facilities. Improvement of watercourses and canal structures in fresh groundwater areas; (d) prevention of saline groundwater intrusion in fresh aquifers. Improvement of watercourses and canals and construction/rehabilitation of drainage facilities in the saline areas; (e) monitoring and evaluation of the project impact; and (f) project management, and technical assistance and training.
 -126- Annex 9 Page 2 of 14 C. Implementation Arrangements 3. General. The project would be implemented by a Project Management Unit (PMU) in the Punjab Planning and Development (P&D) Department, Punjab Irrigation (PID), Agriculture (PAD), and FOs in collaboration with WAPDA. The existing Provincial Policy Committee (PPC) and the Project Coordination Committees (PCC) established under the ongoing Second SCARP Transition Project would provide policy guidance, assist with inter-Departmental coordination, and hold periodic reviews of progress at the provincial and field levels, respectively. The proposed organization is shown in Charts I and 2, and the roles of implementing agencies are described below. 4. The Project management Unit (PMU). The PMU would have minimal staff only for the duration of the project and it would be supported mainly by the consultants. PMU would be composed of a full time Project Director (PD), two ex-officio Members (one each from PID and the Directorate General of Water Management (DGWM), and three Directors as well as support staff. The Directors would be recruited from the open market or supplied by a management consulting firms on fixed-term contracts for the duration of the project. The PD would be a senior official of the P&D Board of the level of Member of the Board. The PMU would be supported by a multi-disciplinary team of consultants who would provide project implementation assistance (PIA) in project management, community mobilization, engineering design and construction supervision, and development of groundwater regulatory framework (terms of reference are in Annex 3). The PMU would also employ an independent organization or consulting firm to carry out project impact evaluation studies (PIES) (TOR are in Annex 6). 5. The PD PMN would be responsible for overseeing overall project implementation. The Director [MIS, Administration, Budget and Accounts (MABA)I would be an experienced Chartered Accountant (or equivalent) with experience in maintaining an MIS, administration, preparation of budgets and maintenance of accounts. With the assistance of the MIS, as well as budget and accounts specialist supplied by the PIA consultants, the Director (MABA) would establish an MIS for the project and submit periodic progress reports on all project components to PMU, and IDA, be responsible for administrative matters relating to the PMU, and prepare annual budgets and requests for appropriation of funds in the Annual Development Programs. The Director [Community Development (CD)] would be a sociologist/anthropologist with experience in community mobilization and participatory irrigation management, preferably in groundwater management. With the assistance of the CDSG teamn supplied by the PIA consultants, the Director (CD) would, inter alia, be responsible for managing and supervising the operations of the project's four field offices, the CDSG team of PIA consultants, and the NGOs involved in community mobilization, maintaining consistency of community mobilization methodology and approach followed by the PIA consultants, OFWM field teams and NGOs. The Director [Regulation] would be a groundwater specialist with experience in legal aspects of groundwater management and regulation, as well as monitoring and evaluation of groundwater projects. The main responsibilities of this position would include managing and supervising the PIE consultants, and the PIA consultants team responsible for developing groundwater regulatory framework. 6. The PID through the Member (Irrigation) of PMU, would be responsible for STWs closures and retrieval of machinery from the boreholes and their capping (this would be done through open auctions), canal rehabilitation/lining, drainage rehabilitation, performance contracts for O&M, and re- deployment of redundant staff. For this purpose, PID would put all the SCARPs included in the project, and one canal construction division under the jurisdiction of the Member (Irrigation). The PAD, through the Directorate General of Water Management, would be responsible for improving watercourses, and establishing FOs and CTWs in designated areas. The DG Water Management would designate a Project Manager, and assign four Area and twenty five Field teams to carry out these
 -127- Annex 9 Page 3 of 14 activities. The Member (Water Management) would, inter alia. be responsible for: (i) ensuring close coordination between the PMU and the Directorate General of Water Management; (ii) drafting necessary bye laws for WUAs and FOs to allow ownership and/or leasing of CTWs/land; and (iii) preparing innovative designs for layout of CTWs so that they could be installed on the public land along the watercourses. 7. NGO's Role. Currently there are no NGOs in Punjab with experience in establishing FOs and capable of assuming full responsibility for managing an extensive social mobilization program needed for the project. However, some local service NGOs have working relationships with local community based organizations CBOs and/or local activists who could help mobilize farmer participation in the project. Wherever feasible, the PMU will seek cooperation of local service NGOs and CBOs either directly or through the PIA consultants to assist with community mobilization. In selecting NGOs/CBOs, it would be ensured that they: (a) are legally registered and maintain accounts that are audited annually; (b) are involved in the rural development as their main objective and they are not affiliated with any political organization; (c) have adequate number of field staff conversant with local languages and customs, and have good knowledge and understanding of the socio-economic conditions in the area; and (d) are supportive of the project objectives and can work in harmony with the rest of the project team. 8. FO's Role. FO's would play a critical role in project implementation. They would be eligible for receiving project assistance for establishing CTWs if they have membership of at least one-third of the farmers within the command of an STW. FOs wishing to establish CTWs would be required to register themselves as a water users association or its sub-group (e.g. a tubewell committee) under the Punjab Water Users Associations Ordinance of 1981. The FOs at the CTW level would, inter alia, have the following responsibilities: (a) interacting with the field tearns of PMU and/or OFWM staff to prepare work plans for transfer of STWs; (b) determining the best option for replacing STW pumpage, in terms of type, size and location of CTWs; (c) installing, operating and maintaining CTW, and distributing water to its members according to agreed shares and schedules; (d) maintaining bank accounts and collecting members' share of capital, operation and maintenance and replacement costs; (e) maintaining capital and O&M accounts and log books; (f) improving water management in the watercourse command; and (f) participating in watercourse and canal improvement programs. 9. Watercourses would be improved in areas where the majority of farrmers on a watercourse agree to cooperate and manage water deliveries at the chak level. In fresh groundwater areas these FOs would qualify for project assistance for watercourse improvements after they have effectively operated and maintained their CTWs for a period of one year. During this period they would: (i) elect their executive committee, including a Chairman, a General Secretary, and a Treasurer; (ii) improve distribution of canal as well as CTW water, and the community and farn channels; (iii) open a bank account, generate funds for up-front contribution for W/C improvement, from sales of CTW water and contributions from FO members; (iv) collect farmers' shares for repayment of material costs to the government; and (v) participate in improving water distribution at the distributary level, and collecting contributions for the capital cost of improving distributaries. 10. WAPDA's Role. WAPDA would provide electric connections to FOs who are close to electric supply and decide to install electric CTWs. Where STWs are converted to CTWs as such under the transfer mode, WAPDA will transfer the title of electrical connection to FOs against normally needed security deposits. WAPDA would also assist FOs in removing electrical equipment and wiring no longer needed.

At the project level, an existing Project Coordination Committee (PCC) would be responsible for ensuring coordination among various agencies and facilitating project implementation. The PCC would be chaired by PD of PMU and have the following members: (i) from PID: SE's of concerned SCARP, canal and drainage Circles; (ii) from the PAD: the Area Coordinator of OFWM; and the Deputy Director Agriculture; (iii) a representative of District Administration; and (iv) representatives of selected FOs. The PCC would meet once every month. The PMU would also act as its secretariat. Provincial Policy Committee 12. The existing Provincial Policy Committee (PPC) would provide policy guidance and steer project implementation by providing inter-agency coordination at the highest level. The PPC would be chaired by the Chairman P&D Board and the Secretaries of Irrigation, Agriculture, and Finance would be its members. The PD of PMU would act as its secretary. The PPC would meet at least every six months, or whenever issues requiring resolution are submitted for its consideration. The main functionls of the PPC would be to: (i) resolve issues not settled by the PCC; (ii) ensure provision of adequate budgetary allocations for project implementation as well as operation and maintenance (O&M); (iii) ensure adequacy and continuity of PMU staff; (iv) ensure that the project complies with legal covenanits; and (v) recruit and supervise consultants to carry out full supervision of the project twice a year, independently of the PMU. Disinvestment of SCARP Tubewells. All field offices would begin to function fully by December, 1996/January 1997. In the first fiscal year only 20 SOs would be in place the number would increase to 60 or more (as needed) in the following years. By June, 1997 about 800 FOs would be formed for installation of CTWs and about 200 STWs would be replaced with 300 CTWs. In project years (PY) two to four about 1,590 CTWs would be installed annually and target of 6,360 would be completed in project year 5. 19. Watercourse (W/C) Improvements. In fresh groundwater area the about 400 watercourse level FOs would be formed by June 30, 1997. Watercourse improvements in fresh area would start from the second year of the project on watercourse where CTWs have worked successfully for one year. It is estimated that about 100 W/Cs would be improved in PY2. The number would increase to 300 in PY3, 600 in PY4 and 500 in the last year. In the saline areas the OFWM staff will concentrate on developing W/C level FOs in the first project year. In the PY2 about 50 watercourse would be improved, about 200 in PY3 and PY4, and about 50 in PY5. 20. Canal Improvements. Preparation of detailed canal designs would start in January, 1996 and would be completed by November 30, 1997. The tender documents would be finalized by December 31, 1997. The bids would be invited through ICB in January, 1998 and the work would start in July, 1998. About 30 percent of the works would be completed in PY3 followed by 40 and 30 percent in PY4 and PY S. 21. Drainage Works. If required supervision would occur more frequently during the first two years to help steer it through the start-up stage. The project launchi and procurement workshops would also be organized during this period. The IDA supervision would comprise of one main supervision mission annually in the second semester of the fiscal year, supplemented by a shorter mission in the first semester, and correspondence and clearances as needed. Intensity of supervision missions would be reduced after the project is successfully past this start-up stage, and a regime of enihanced Government has been established. Intensive IDA supervision during the start-up stage is justified given the nature of the project, which unlike conventional irrigation projects, is "software" intensive rather than "hardware" intensive. Community mobilization is a crucial element of the project. This is a relatively new area in irrigation projects in Pakistan and requires greater supervision inputs by IDA. Table 3 contains IDA's proposed supervision plan, and details of staff inputs and skill mix requirements for supervision missions. IDA supervision would be facilitated by the proposed arrangemenits for enhanced Government supervision. Borrowers Contribution to Supervision 24. The PMU would have a lead role in supervision the project implementation, and responsible for ensuring that all project components are appropriately monitored, based on the key indicators and regularly measured to give an idea of the project's impact and success in meeting its objectives. The PMU would have primary responsibility for re-directing and restructuring of the project, chaniginig the levels and types of inputs, and processes to ensure that the project objectives are met and implemenitationi proceeds smoothly and according to the schedule. The PMU would make use of the moniitoring and evaluation studies, Management Information Systems and budgeting and accounting meclianiisins and third party supervision for rigorous superior of the project. 25. Third Party Supervision. In line with the decision taken during the 1995 Country Portfolio Perfornmance Review (CPPR), the project provides resources to support enhanced project supervision by GOPunjab. The P&D Board would hire, independently of the PMU, services of specialists in various fields to carry out detailed supervision of the project on behalf of GOPunjab from time to time (on average two times a year) and submit detailed supervision reports. TOR of these specialists as well as their reports would be shared with IDA. 26. Annual Work Plans and Progress Reporting. The MIS of the PMU would be designed to meet the monitoring and reporting requirements of all project components. The PIA consultants would identify the key progress indicators and design an appropriate MIS system, including an "issues and actions oriented" progress reporting format acceptable to the PMU and IDA. The PMU, with inputs from PID and PAD, would also prepare detailed annual plans/work programs and budgets, as well as requests for allocation of funds in the federal/provincial annual development programs. The annual plans would duly take into account feedback from project impact evaluation studies. The PID and PAD would submit monthly progress reports to the PMU. The PMU in turn would integrate them and submit periodic progress reports covering all project components to the P&D Board, PID, PAD and IDA. The PMU would also periodically prepare working papers for the PCC and PPC meetings. Assurances would be obtained that by March 31 each year, the PMU would submit to IDA for its review, a draft Annual Plan, including work program and the proposed budgetary allocation for the following fiscal year, cleared by the PPC.
 Annex 9 -131- Page 7 of 14 27. Project Launch Workshop. To facilitate project start-up. the PMU in collaboration with PID and PAD, would hold a project launch workshop soon after Credit signing (in early FY97). The workshop would, inter alia, familiarize project staff (as well as officials of concerned implementing and cooperating agencies) with the project objectives, components, implementation schedule and institutional arrangements, procurement and disbursement procedures, and monitoring and evaluation aspects of the project. 28. Procurement Workshops. Several procurement workshops would be conducted to provide assistance in the procurement planning, the use of Banks Standard Bidding document, preparation of bid documents, evaluation of bids and award of contracts. These workshops would be organized to train local staff in procurement with the aim to enhance general capability in this area and, in addition to the project staff will be open to staff of other agencies involved in procurement under large projects. 29. Mid-Term Review. To evaluate the project's progress, and prospects of meeting its objectives, a detailed mid-term review (MTR) would be carried out jointly by GOPunjab, GOP and IDA during the third year of implementation, not latter than March 31, 1999. The MTR would evaluate the overall progress and assess need for adjustments in the project scope and design, implementation approach and methodology, and policy aspects, to ensure timely completion and achievement of project objectives. The PMU would submit draft TOR for the MTR for the P&D Board's and IDA's review by September 30, 1998, and an MTR Preparation Report compiled with the assistance of the PIA and PIE consultants, or other specialists by January 31, 1999.

doc.repnme: Pakistan - Punjab Private Sector Groundwater Development Project
doc.abstracts: The overall objectives of the Punjab Private Sector Groundwater Development Project are to increase the scope and productivity of Punjab's irrigation and drainage subsector and increase farmers' incomes. The specific objectives are to: (a) redefine Government's role in groundwater development and provide assistance to facilitate change; (b) develop a monitoring program and regulatory framework to ensure sustainable use of the groundwater resources; (c) develop sustainable farmers' organizations; (d) increase beneficiaries' incomes and alleviate poverty; (e) rationalize public expenditure on operation and management of the irrigation and drainage systems as well as increase the recovery of public expenditures on irrigation infrastructure; and (f) avoid environmental hazard of saline water intrusion into fresh groundwater aquifers. The project covering a large part of fresh groundwater Salinity Control and Reclamation Project (SCARP) areas in Punjab will be implemented over a period of five years. The major components are: (a) disinvestment of SCARP tubewells; (b) development of a groundwater monitoring and regulatory framework; (c) improvement of irrigation conveyance facilities; (d) prevention of saline groundwater intrusion in fresh aquifers; (e) monitoring and evaluation of the project; and (f) project management, and technical assistance and training.
